Description: A hollow terracotta camel with a saddle, modelled in the round. Suspension-holes are pierced through neck and rump; horizontal holes through the front of the saddle. Two-piece mould. Pink Aswan kaolinite ware, with mica. Yellow slip overall. Eyes and details of harness in black fired-on ceramic colour; orange colour round throat, over hollow of saddle, and on the tail.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Akhmim (Panopolis). Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Close, probably same mould-series: Rutschowscaya and Bénazeth 2000: 196, no. 220, dated Byzantine period = Goyon 2000: 171, no. 131, dated fourth to seventh century AD. Near: Boutantin 2004: 11, figs 10, 12 and 13, the last from Memphis, all dated fifth to sixth century AD; Goyon 2000: 171, no. 133, dated Roman period; Petrie Museum uc48033, from Memphis; Spencer 1989: pl. 84:177, from Hermopolis Magna, dated sixth to seventh century AD. Bibliog: Boutantin 2004: 11, fig. 11, dated fifth to sixth century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3765)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
